page.title: 03DRIFT GEOLOGY IN LAMLASH.
page.content: The rocky deposits which constitute Lamlash are mainly made up of boulder clay.This was deposited during the ice age which occured in the Pliestocone period.These boulder clays are mainly found on the higher areas of ground.On the very high areas (up to 300m),there are moraines.These probably came from the granite area in the North of the island,and were carried down in a Southerly direction by the glaciers. In the Cnoc Dubh area there is a triangular deposit of red sandstone. This is enclosed by a series of pitch stone dykes.The dykes evolved before the sandstones and this is why the sandstone deposits were prevented from moving any further.The farming and the housing areas of Lamlash are built on intermediate beaches.This is why farming in Lamlash has always been popular due to the partly sandy soils.
